messageBody:
To add to what Vladimir was saying, I've needed to override the way tests
are launched and managed. Because of the way the test runners are
implemented (in the junit.framework.BaseTestRunner hierarchy), we ended up
duplicating code in subclasses of the runner views. I agree that there's way
too much replication in functionality between the different flavors of test
runners. It bit me several times. Note: by view, I mean whatever is
responsible for the presentation and control behavior.

For me, it would be advantageous to be able to provide arbitrary test
runners that implement a test runner interface (whatever that turns out to
be) to the views. If done right, it can live in parallel with the current
implementation for a couple of iterations.

Here's a very simple test case off the top of my head that shows what I
mean:

import junit.framework.*;
public class TestRunner extends junit.framework.TestCase implements
TestListener {
int errorCount;
int failureCount;
ITestRunner runner;
String testClassName= "junit.samples.money.MoneyTest";

public void synchronousTestRunnerTest() {
runner= new SynchronousTestRunner(testClassName);

// Perhaps needing to instantiate the runner under a try/catch block for
// ClassNotFoundException, etc. would be better than this. Thoughts?
assertTrue(runner.testClassIsValid());

// In my case, the count of test cases was derived from
// the actual count and other parameters, so going through
// the runner for the count would be preferred
assertEquals(runner.countTestCases(),21);

runner.addListener(this);
runner.start();

// With the synchronous test runner here, you can assume it is done after
// returning from start(). With an asynchronous test runner, you would
// need to be notified of completion, which implies extending the
// listener interface.
validateResult(result);

public void validateResult(ITestResult result) {
// Simple result assertions. If I knew that the runner returned
// results that included other arbitrary information, I
// would cast and assert appropriately.
ITestResult result= runner.getResult();
assertTrue(result.getExecutionTime() > 0);
assertEquals(result.getTestsRun(),21);
assertEquals(result.getFailureCount(),0);
assertEquals(result.getErrorCount(),0);

// Simple listener assertions
assertEquals(result.getFailureCount(),failureCount);
assertEquals(result.getErrorCount(),errorCount);
}

public void addError(Test test, Throwable t) {
errorCount++;
}

public void addFailure(Test test, Throwable t) {
failureCount++;
}


Let's say we add the following to TestListener:
/**
* The entire test has completed
*/
public void testComplete(Test test);

Then we can do the following to test an asynchronous test runner, if one
were ever needed. I've eliminated some of the stuff that would have been
repetitions of the above. Note: To do this right, we would add a timer to
fail the test if it does not complete within a reasonable time.

public void asynchronousTestRunnerTest() {
runner= new AsynchronousTestRunner(testClassName);
runner.addListener(this);

// Asynchronously spawn test
runner.start();
}

public void testComplete(Test test) {
validateResult(runner.getResult());
}

> One refactoring could improve the internal API: the rerun method
> is duplicated
> in the AWT and Swing runners. Move this method to the BaseTestRunner.
>
> The following refactorings are a natural consequence of the first one:
>
> - move all run methods into the BaseTestRunner (so that every
> runners can run a
> Test or a Class or a TestSuite)
> - replace all the abstract methods (used to communicate with the
> AWT, Swing and
> Text runners by a listener.
> - hide the TestResult completely and only let clients communicate with the
> listener.
>
> And it looks very nice :-) Hopefully a future release will look
> nice too. I'm
> working on it.
